section.heading: Definition.
section.text: "Board" means the Board of Examiners in Optometry.

para.text: Preprofessional education—completion of 2 years of pre-optometric college study in an accredited institution of higher learning or its equivalent.
Professional education — completion of 4 scholastic years at:
An accredited college of optometry;
An accredited university school of optometry; or
An equivalent of §B(1) or (2) of this regulation.
The Board will accept applications for examination from graduates of those colleges of optometry or university schools of optometry:
Endorsed by the Association of Regulatory Boards of Optometry (ARBO); and
Accredited by the Council on Optometric Education of the American Optometric Association.
An applicant shall complete and file an application on the form provided by the Board on request.
The applicant shall submit the following information:
Full name, residence, and date and place of birth;
A recent photograph of the applicant;
Letters of recommendation from three individuals, excluding immediate family members, who can attest to the applicant's character and reputation;
All final professional transcripts of colleges or university schools of optometry;
A fee, established by the Board, which shall accompany the application;
Preprofessional transcripts.
Application fees are not refundable.
Applicants shall be notified whether they meet the standards adopted by the Board and qualify for licensure.
The Board shall require and give any combination of written, oral, clinical, and practical examination.
Subjects for Examination. The following subjects may be included in the written, oral, clinical, and practical examinations:
Optometric jurisprudence;
Theoretic optics;
Ophthalmic optics;
Physiological and psychological optics;
Optometry—theoretic and practical;
Visual fields;
Clinical examination;
Anatomy (ocular and general);
Physiology (ocular and general);
Pathology (ocular and general);
Vision training and orthoptic training;
Contact lenses;
Low vision;
Tonometry;
Biomicroscopy;
Pharmacology;
Physiology;
Developmental vision;
Primary care.
The Board may require candidates for licensure to take all or part of the National Board of Examiners in Optometry's written examinations.

A candidate for licensure, other than a candidate qualified under Health Occupations Article, §11-305, Annotated Code of Maryland, shall obtain a score of 300 on the basic science part, a score of 300 on the clinical science part, and a score of 300 on the patient care part of the National Board of Examiners in Optometry (NBEO) examinations.
A candidate for licensure shall obtain a grade of 75 on the Maryland Board of Examiners in Optometry jurisprudence examination.

section.heading: Waiver of Examination.
section.text: Standards for licensure with partial waiver of examination are set forth in Health Occupations Article, §11-305, Annotated Code of Maryland.

section.heading: License Renewal.
section.text: A license holder shall pay to the Board every 2 years, on or before July 1 of the renewal year, a fee for renewal to be established by the Board.

para.text: An optometrist shall notify the Board of the optometrist's principal address in Maryland.
An optometrist shall report a change of principal address within 30 days.
